title: Milton Creek Country Park Walking and Cycle Route

images.title: Chelb, CC BY-SA 4.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Milton Creek Country Park Play Area

images.title: Richard Dorrell / Drain and flood bund
images.caption: Drain and flood bund Looking east south east towards Kemsley Marshes and Milton Creek. The houses on the right are the edge of the Church Milton development. The footpath runs along the top of the flood bund into the newly created Church Marshes Country Park (now known as Milton Creek Country Park).

images.title: David Anstiss / Footbridge over Marsh Stream
images.caption: Footbridge over Marsh Stream Footpath from Beauvoir Drive (unseen, otherside of embankment) leads to Playing field (just to right of photo) at end of Eadred Way. Stream and embankment footpath leads to Grovehurst Road, they are part of the Country Park, which is open land on the Swale.

images.title: Richard Dorrell / Fishing pond in Church Marshes Country Park
images.caption: Fishing pond. This pond existed long before the Country Park had been created. It was possibly originally a clay pit for the local brickworks. The pond has now been tidied up, with new paths and fishing access platforms. A permit is required to fish here.

images.title: New trees in Milton Creek Country Park by David Anstiss, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: New trees planted in the park. Wildlife here includes redshank, black-tailed godwit, teal and grey plover.

images.title: Sittingbourne and Kemsley Light Railway to Sittingbourne by David Anstiss, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Sittingbourne and Kemsley Light Railway. The narrow gauge heritage railway operates from Sittingbourne to the banks of The Swale. The line was built in 1905 for the transportation of the raw materials required for the manufacture of paper. It continues to use the old steam engines and rolling stock as a local attraction.

images.title: Milton Creek, near Sittingbourne by Chris Whippet, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Milton Creek. The site was once called Church Marshes Country Park. Church Marshes is at the base of Kemsley Down on the banks of Milton Creek where it flows into the Swale, a tidal channel of the Thames estuary.

images.title: Saxon Shore Way to Kemsley by David Anstiss, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Saxon Shore Way to Kemsley

description: A short circular cycle or walk around Milton Creek Country Park in Sittingbourne in Kent. The park is set in 128 acres and contains Milton Creek, fishing lakes and a network of well laid out paths. The heritage Sittingbourne and Kemsley Light Railway also runs though the Park. The nearby Kemsley railway station makes for a good access point for the route.
